text: It is early in the morning when I rise. The light of day has yet to grace this side of the earth with its presence. No longer do I need my alarm; my very instinct, something deep within, tells me when it is time to awake. Gathering my surfboard, a swimsuit, and other necessary equipment, I step outside and pause at the bottom of the stairs. Listening intently, I realize that the shouts from the amusement parks have not started, and the noise of civilization has yet to arrive. Everything is virtually silent save the waves crashing in a location just beyond my view and the summer gulls trying to collect their food for the day.

School lunch is honestly a mix of good and bad. Some days the food is actually decent, like pizza or chicken sandwiches, but other days it’s kind of weird and nobody wants it. The worst part is the lines take forever, so by the time you sit down, you barely have time to eat. I usually bring snacks just in case, because I never know if I’ll like what they serve. I think they should give more choices so people don’t waste food.

As I sit on the sand, still cool from the previous night, with my board by my feet, I realize beyond a doubt that I am the luckiest person on the planet. The waves are breaking in perfect sets of four, some splashing into the jetties, while others make their way to greet me on the shore. I take a moment to close my eyes, and everything is free and completely at rest. Like the pieces of even the most intricate puzzle, everything just fits.

I feel like phones should be allowed in class, but only at certain times. Some teachers act like phones are the biggest problem ever, but they can actually help if you need to look something up fast. The real issue is people being on TikTok or texting during lessons. If students had a rule like “phones face down unless the teacher says,” it would be fair. Taking phones away completely just makes people more sneaky.

Then it starts to happen. This is something I have been a witness to on countless occasions before, yet it still never ceases to amaze me and never will. The sun, the very light of the world, begins to make its appearance over the distant, ever-present yet mysterious horizon. It is almost as though a giant light switch has been flipped on as glorious rays of silken purples, radiant pinks and delicate blues shine bright. The sun’s likeness reflects off of the vast ocean waters in front of me, and, despite its blinding qualities, it is mesmerizing. I do not blink at all, for fear I will miss a single second of the sight that is far too beautiful for words: something beyond mere mortal comprehension.

This weekend wasn’t super exciting, but it was nice. On Saturday I slept in and then went to the store with my mom, which was boring at first but we got Starbucks so it wasn’t that bad. Later I played games with my friends online and we stayed up kind of late. On Sunday I had to do homework and it stressed me out because I forgot about one assignment. I’m glad the weekend happened but I wish it was longer.

Now, almost as quickly as it had begun, it fades away before ceasing. The moment in time connecting the opposites night and day is gone. The sky shines clear and blue and the coolness of the night before vanishes. The day has brought its life and night has been chased away under its vanishing horizon to bring darkness and mystery to the rest of the world, before making its return.

Playing sports teaches you more than just how to win. It helps you learn teamwork and how to stay calm even when you’re losing. I used to get really nervous before games, but after a while I got used to the pressure. Sometimes it’s annoying when practices take up so much time, especially with homework, but it feels good to improve. Even if you’re not the best on the team, being part of it still matters.

Big Daddy attended Texas State University so he could be a tailor, while Be-Bop, as he called my grandmother after the sock hop jazz music that was popular when they met, eagerly pursued her dream of working as a seamstress. Big Daddy had to work two jobs while he was in school, so Mamo was always there to help him study. From his books she learned how to run a business, a set of skills she continues to use as a self-employed seamstress.

One goal I have this year is to manage my time better. I always tell myself I’ll start homework early, but then I end up doing it late at night and rushing. It makes me feel tired the next day and I hate that feeling. I think if I used a planner or even a notes app, it would help a lot. I don’t need to be perfect, but I want to stop stressing out so much.

The ancient stories are full of enchanters who are weavers and seamstresses. Rumpelstiltskin and Maleficent understood that thread and silk had the power to shape lives and worlds. They knew that life is not about the fabric you weave but the dreams you create, not about the change that occurs when straw is spun into gold but the metamorphosis of the human spirit. Mamo has just turned sixty-nine years old and is full of vitality and light. In the letters I write to her on her birthday and each Mother’s Day, I liken her to splendid objects such as Mexican ceramics or a flock of butterflies. She wields a brilliant magic – one that allowed a heartbroken sharecropper’s daughter to take silk and tresses, joy and love, and form the life she wanted and the family she treasures. And as much as any child she has raised or any dress she has sewn, she herself is truly a masterpiece.

My favorite season is fall because everything feels calmer. The weather isn’t too hot or too cold, and you can actually wear hoodies without sweating. I also like how the leaves change colors and the air smells different. Fall makes school feel more organized, like it’s a fresh start. Plus, holidays are coming up, so it gives you something to look forward to.

I groaned. My whopping three hours of sleep had not served me well. I rolled over and saw Andrew looking up at me. Andrew had dark hair, a yellowish tone of skin and eyes with a slight slant to them—Asian. In fact, everyone in the room was Asian, excluding myself.

I watched a movie recently that was way better than I expected. At first I thought it would be boring because the beginning was slow, but then it started getting more intense. The characters actually felt realistic and not fake. I liked that it had funny moments but still had a serious message. After it ended, I kept thinking about it, which is how you know it was good.

I was amazed at how quickly I assimilated into the social world of the Chinese Church. It was the first time I had ever felt “popular,” so naturally I continued to return. It was a wonderful atmosphere—a place where I could worship the God I loved and enjoy the company of the people who seemed like me—not externally, but internally. As I continued to return to the Chinese church, a lot of my “friends” made fun of me. They called me an “inverse Twinkie,” a clever racial slur referring to Caucasian people who are under the impression that they’re Asian. I simply smiled and played along. I found that I cared less and less what they thought—I had discovered a place I loved, a place I belonged, and I was happy. The reason I fit in so well with the youth group was a bit oblique at first, but eventually it became obvious to me. They’re scholarly people, intelligent; they love God and have a knack for computers—which also happens to be a perfect description of myself. I climbed out of bed and got dressed. I was sore from the previous night’s festivities—nothing quite like Frisbee Football, or Ultimate Frisbee as my Oriental friends had dubbed the game. I smiled to myself as I walked down the dimly-lit hallways of the campus. “I am at home,” I thought.

If I looked through my sock drawer, I am sure that I would find many more stories, many more places. I know, for instance, that there are some mottled gray wools with holes that could reminisce about cold-weather camping trips with Boy Scout Troop 10. They might also tell of the times they served to replace the ripped cloth boots from my roller blades. Perhaps, though, they would just complain about being neglected of late, in favor of the two newer pairs of softer, less itchy wool-blends; the ones that talk of churches, and also speak of sandals. Or maybe they would fault the black, thick dress wools with the elastic all stretched out (they have tales to tell about frigid marching band shows with the cuffs of the flannel pants I wore under my uniform tucked in so they wouldn’t show) for being part of what has kept me from camping and skating for the last four years.

Social media can be fun, but it also gets stressful fast. You can scroll for five minutes and suddenly it turns into an hour without you realizing it. Sometimes it makes you compare your life to other people’s, even though you know it’s not completely real. I think it’s good for staying connected, but it can mess with your mood. Taking breaks from it actually helps more than people admit.

It seemed a strange idea initially, but when my friend Alvin invited me to come on a previous retreat of the Cincinnati Chinese Church six months before I figured it was better than gazing at a glowing monitor all weekend. I had been having trouble making friends at my family’s church; they just weren’t the kind of people I fit in with. The youth at my parent’s church seemed to me the perfect stereotype of teenagers—no ambition, only caring about the moment, and doing everything for the sole purpose of fitting in. I dreaded going to church each Sunday; I didn’t want to become one of these people. The Cincinnati Chinese Church offered a fresh start.

School stress is real, especially when everything is due at the same time. Teachers will say “you have a week” but then you have five other classes doing the same thing. It’s not even always the work, it’s the constant pressure to keep up. I wish we had more time during school to work on assignments. It would help students who don’t have a quiet place at home or who have responsibilities after school.

In a typical U.S. high school classroom, students often raise their hands before speaking and address the teacher respectfully. They may ask questions when they do not understand a topic and are generally encouraged to participate in discussions. Teachers usually create an open environment where students feel comfortable sharing their opinions, even if they are unsure. This interaction helps build confidence and supports active learning.

Junior high school students in the United States usually interact with their teachers in a polite but relaxed manner. While they are expected to follow classroom rules, teachers often use a friendly tone and encourage students to speak up. Students may approach the teacher after class to ask for clarification or help with assignments, showing a balance between respect and approachability.

High school students often communicate with teachers through class discussions, emails, or learning platforms. They are encouraged to express their thoughts clearly and ask for feedback on their work. Teachers appreciate when students show effort and responsibility, such as completing assignments on time and participating thoughtfully during lessons.

In many U.S. classrooms, students are taught to collaborate with peers while also respecting the teacher’s authority. Group work is common, and students may discuss ideas openly before sharing them with the class. Teachers guide conversations and provide support rather than strict instruction at all times.

American junior high classrooms often focus on helping students build communication skills. Teachers ask questions to the class and expect students to respond using complete sentences. Even when students make mistakes, teachers usually respond positively and encourage them to keep trying.

High school students are generally expected to take more responsibility for their learning. They may schedule time to talk with teachers about grades or future goals. This interaction helps students develop independence while maintaining a respectful relationship with their instructors.

Classroom interaction in U.S. schools often includes informal conversations, especially at the beginning or end of class. Teachers may ask students how they are doing, creating a supportive atmosphere. This helps students feel valued and more engaged in the learning process.

Students in American schools are usually encouraged to ask questions during lessons. Teachers view questions as a sign of interest rather than a disruption. This culture promotes curiosity and helps students better understand the material being taught.

Respect is an important part of student-teacher interaction in U.S. classrooms. Students are expected to listen when the teacher is speaking and follow instructions. At the same time, teachers often show respect by listening carefully to student opinions and concerns.

Overall, interaction between students and teachers in U.S. junior high and high schools tends to be interactive and supportive. Teachers act as guides, while students are encouraged to participate actively, ask questions, and communicate openly in a respectful manner.

We started the day with Atlas’ producer of the day presentation on Sophie, which was really interesting and gave us all a deep dive into how much influence she had on the music scene. Today was a particularly exciting day, as it was the first time we started the DJing part of our M-Term. We were once again joined by Mr. Trevino, who not only taught us the basics of the skill itself but also gave us insights into his lifestyle and career as a DJ. We all downloaded Serato DJ Lite, a free DJing software that allowed us to take two songs and mash them up with our expert's guidance. We learned how to download and input songs, how to match tempos (beats per minute) and key signatures, and finally, how to mix volumes in order to properly transition between songs. We had the chance to download our own songs and experiment with the different elements that determined whether songs were compatible or not in creating an enjoyable auditory experience. I originally attempted “Black Star” by Radiohead and “Your Latest Trick” by Dire Straits, which proved to be a disaster due to extremely different tempos. We also all had the opportunity to use two smaller pieces of equipment for DJing, and got to try a larger piece of equipment owned by Mr. Trevino which was a lot of fun and much more intuitive than working solely on the computer.

Our activity today was we were given a little bit of time to think of or research different genres, and then you’d be given two sheets of paper to write two selected genres, fold them up, and place them in a bucket to be picked at random by someone else. Everyone was hard at work researching their topics, and after a 10-minute break at around 11, everyone took turns giving brief explanations of their topics, with characteristics such as Tempo, Rhythm, Tonality, Melody, etc… Afterwards, we spent the rest of the day working to create a song of that genre, where a few people presented what they had. And that concludes the first week of Music Production and DJing!

To start off our Thursday, we listened to our classmate Khushi give an excellent presentation on her producer of choice before initiating a scavenger hunt; the idea was to find at least five sounds in our environment either created by us or occurring naturally, record them, and then create a song on FL studio incorporating those sounds. We all had so much fun finding unique sounds to input into our music and enjoyed sharing our (sometimes questionable) creations with each other. Once it was time for lunch, Mr Roddy drove us to our first record store of the term, Sig’s Lagoon, where we spent at least half an hour scouring through the countless vinyls and even making some purchases. We made a pit stop to Levy Park to eat our lunch and rest before we went to get some ice cream at Amy’s. Finally, we went to our second record store, Cactus Music, where we found (and bought) so many cool music-related items. We headed back to school to enjoy some time together and share our findings, making for a perfect ending to an already great day.

For the final day of the first week in Music Production and DJ’ing, we focused a lot on exploring different music genres. While producing music, it's typical to stick to a style that you’re familiar with, but this was a good exercise in getting out of our comfort zone and also just learning about new music genres!
